story:
What is Operation Red Alert?

Red Alert is a MOVEMENT to end large-scale sex trafficking in India by 2025.

Red Alert aims to be the VOICE against sex trafficking in India, bringing scale and power through a large networks of grassroots anti-sex trafficking organizations.

Operation Red Alert has strategically positioned its work to do exactly what our name suggests - to raise awareness and put every person in India on alert for trafficking. We believe that if you and I are on red alert, then one more girl will not be trafficked.


 

Sex Trafficking in India:

  • Every 10 minutes a girl gets sold into the Indian flesh trade.
  • A girl in an Indian brothel is RAPED 20 times or more in a day.
  • ONLY 1% of these girls are rescued.
  • The average age of a trafficked child in India is 12 years old, with some victims being as young as 7 years old.
  • India has more slaves than any other country. An estimated 14 million by the global slavery index.

 

Why a comic book?

Read the comic here

India is largely an illiterate country. So using strong graphics that are informative, set in the local context and limited dialogue, can be a very powerful tool in creating awareness. The messaging is designed to be uniform throughout the comic, addressing issues such as domestic violence, sex trafficking, child sexual abuse, child marriage and dowry - both in subtle and bold messaging. We have also created flyers for each of the members in a family (i.e father, mother, girl, boy) that go along with the comics to strengthen and reinforce the messaging.

It as an effective communication tool. The graphics are engaging to both young and old. It is set in the local context so that people can relate to the specific characters and even aspire to be like them. Our approach is to see positive change. To present an example to the people and show them that it is possible to be like that.

Meet the Characters:

Vijai

The Good Father

Our approach to the fathers is to point out to them that they are good fathers and to inspire them to be that Good Father. With our messaging, we also encourage them to keep their daughters in school, make sure their daughters are safe and not to get them married before the legal age. All of these will prevent trafficking.


 

Jaya

The Informed Mother

The mothers messaging is quite unique, as the role of a woman is many times overlooked in India. In the comic the mother plays an active part in decision making and sharing information. Our messaging to the mothers including motivating her to speak up when domestic violence, abuse, child marriage or selling a daughter is happening. We encourage them if they ever do need help - we are always there with our Helpline.

 

Rani

The Guardian Girl

This came from the question- who is the best person to look after a girl? The answer we found was - The girl herself.  We want to equip girls to take of themselves and to take care of their friends.

Rahul

The “Cool” Boy

The Hindi work we use is “Hatke” which means “Different”. Different in a Cool way. We want to encourage the young boys and men that a change starts with them. If they respect girls, the village will be a safe villages for girls.

Another key message for boys is to be honourable men. The reason why we encourage the boys is, they are possible migrant workers that go to the cities for better job opportunities. Statistics have shown that these young men have high possibility of being brothel customers. Therefore if we can encourage them to be honourable before they go, we believe they will be more convicted not to be customers when they are in the city.

Wanna meet a Guardian Girl?

National Helpline

Besides the comic books, we have successfully set up a national helpline specifically for child sex trafficking. Until now, access to help for victims or potential victims has been hard to come by - especially for the victim to reach out for help. We have partnered with several  reputable NGOs who work at the grassroots level, and it is with their help that we can deliver a service to the callers.

 

Partnering with Facebook

We have also partnered with Facebook's free internet initiative "Free Basics" to set up a very informative, mobile-optimised website (MyRights) that provides crucial information that a woman might need in case of harassment, abuse and other social issues in India. Our content is available in four  regional  languages already and we aim to have it in the 22 major regional languages as soon as possible. 

Where’s the money going?

We have done a lot of research, development and networking. So funds are not only going to forward funding, but retro funding as well. All funds will be directed to our most crucial effort first and foremost - the Village Toolkit. The Toolkit is the prevention-education kit that our rural program depends on. 

This includes:

  • Comic Book development costs including the design of characters, script writing, pages layout etc. 
  • Printing costs of the comics and flyers (flyers are supplement pages inside the comic books that speak directly to each stake holder). India has a population of 1.252 billion people. That is going to be a lot of comics! We've started with 60,000 in each language of our 2015 strategic target zones. 
  • Translation costs for the comic book from English to Bengali, Telugu and Hindi. Our goal is to provide these resources in all main local languages. In 2015 our target zones required 3 language translations. 
  • Distribution costs of the comic. India has over 640,000 villages. That is a lot of ground to cover! We have to get the comics and flyers to these villages as well as the people doing the awareness campaign. So it’s going to include a lot of travelling and for our trainers to stay in the villages for 2 nights while they conduct the awareness campaign. In 2015 we are reaching out to the first 240 villages between October - December. 
  • Training costs. Crucial to our success is our ability to train local area coordinators on how to use these tools to do an effective awareness campaign. We have completed 4 training programmes in September/October 2015 as part of our stage 1 outreach. These 4 training programmes have trained over 200 trainers who are now ready to go and conduct the two-day awareness campaigns and successfully distribute and discuss the comics and flyers. We don’t just want to distribution, it is important to discuss the issues covered in the comics. That is why we have a two-day programme where proper education about these issues can be done.


Our Approach:

With 18 months of intensive research we came up with very unique messaging on anti-trafficking and anti-domestic violence. We have moved away from the conventional DO’s and DON’Ts message and developed a positive message approach. This approach to our messaging was informed by first of its kind research we commissioned from the Behavioral Architects of Final Mile who have worked with the Indian Government, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation as well as the UN and many others.  The Final Mile research provided many critical insights into the compulsions of men on the supply and demand side, but quite significantly it found that pointing out the inherent and aspirational good that is in all of us is a much more effective and receivable approach than trying to create shock, outrage or anger about an issue. 

The Story Behind Our Comic Book

We have used the research and input from many on the ground NGO and partners and came up with a very interactive comic book. We have already developed Volume 1 and distributed it in villages. It has been received with an overwhelmingly positive response from literate school girls and illiterate parents alike! 

This comic book series will serve as a tool that will bring awareness about the issue of sex trafficking. The characters become the voice of awareness, not being too shy or too bound by culture to speak about these issues.

The characters are easy for the local people to relate to and the graphics are designed so that all people will enjoy them.

We have translated the comic book and flyers into 3 languages and the next 3 are in process. Local language adaptation is necessary because India's diversity means that literacy comes in 22 major languages with over 720 dialects! We aim to provide each community with resources in their local language. 

"Nothing happens just because we are aware of modern day slavery, but nothing will ever happen until we are."  - Gary Haugen
story_txt:
What is Operation Red Alert?Red Alert is a MOVEMENT to end large-scale sex trafficking in India by 2025.Red Alert aims to be the VOICE against sex trafficking in India, bringing scale and power through a large networks of grassroots anti-sex trafficking organizations.Operation Red Alert has strategically positioned its work to do exactly what our name suggests - to raise awareness and put every person in India on alert for trafficking. We believe that if you and I are on red alert, then one more girl will not be trafficked. Sex Trafficking in India:
Every 10 minutes a girl gets sold into the Indian flesh trade.
A girl in an Indian brothel is RAPED 20 times or more in a day.
ONLY 1% of these girls are rescued.
The average age of a trafficked child in India is 12 years old, with some victims being as young as 7 years old.
India has more slaves than any other country. An estimated 14 million by the global slavery index.

story: ADK
story_txt: ADK

story:
"With so much violence, hatred and terror in the world around us there seems to be no space to speak and organize around issues that face transgender, queer and gender non-conforming people of color. That's why we've created the #BlackExcellenceTour, to fight back against the injustices we face everyday." – CeCe McDonald

In 2016 Joshua Allen and CeCe McDonald started the #BlackExcellenceTour as a social justice project that combats violence against trans, gender non-conforming and queer people of color. We use art, activism, and storytelling to bring attention to issues affecting our communities and to begin having discussions about justice, freedom and equality that includes those living at the intersection of marginal identities.

Doing this work has been extremely rewarding and challenging. Throughout this past year alone we've facilitated workshops, delivered keynotes, and led discussions around these issues in over 18 cities and reached thousands of people. Unfortunately there is a real lack of funding and support for our grassroots organizing work.

With rollbacks in basic human rights protections and rising trends in violence and incarceration that disproportionately impacts trans and gender non-conforming people of color it is more important now than ever that we fund resistance that is for and by the people most impacted!

The #BlackExcellenceTour is rooted in the tradition of civil rights and anti-apartheid activists, as we bring the perspectives and power of black, queer, trans/gender non-conforming and femme lives to our organizing, education, and advocacy. We center those who have been most marginalized. We share knowledge and build power to dismantle the systemic and structural oppression we live within. We fight back against forces working to render us silent and reclaim our bodies, voices, and lives.

We need funding to build power and support community organizing efforts for the upcoming year.  We will present free public workshops and trainings, and organize direct actions to address policing, prison abolition, body autonomy, reproductive justice, trans resilience, and other areas of immediate concern and impact in this harrowing time.  We begin our work in our local communities, and build national and international connections and momentum. Together we organize and build power, voice, and visibility, to bring about truly transformational change.

Support the #BlackExcellenceTour today to uplift trans resilience, black love, and organizing for us by us!

Who We Are:

CeCe McDonald is a black trans woman, activist & speaker. Rising to international recognition after surviving a white supremacist & transphobic attack, CeCe has quickly become an icon in the LGBTQ community. She fosters important conversations around mass incarceration, sexuality & violence and is the star of the recently released feature length documentary about her life & story, Free Cece!

Joshua Allen is a community organizer and abolitionist whose work revolves around issues of race, gender and policing. Their work of coordinating direct actions, movement building and analyzing the intersections of race and gender has been a beacon of inspiration for communities seeking change. At 21, Joshua is recognized as leading the cutting edge of new social & political movements. They have organized campaigns for justice in countries across the globe.

Upcoming #BlackExcellenceTour Stops:

3/17- Haverford College

4/4- Florida State University

4/6- Syracuse University

story:
Mission

LIVE A GREAT STORY is heading to Port-au-Prince, Haiti for a focused trip on Sakala, a children's community center in the heart of one of the world's most dangerous and underprivileged areas.

Our mission has two focuses 1) take supplies to further the Sakala mission, contribute manpower, investigate future action, discuss overall assistance program for Haiti 2) capture footage about the Sakala story for a media campaign for continued efforts to support their cause.

The really cool part is that each donation makes 3X the impact! 

So check it out : when you donate to this trip, your money impacts 3 areas. 

1) It goes towards supplies going into Haiti. We're taking a bunch of things down there to use in sports, gardening and education

2) It goes towards supplies coming back from Haiti. ALL OF THE PERKS are made in Haiti, so each item directly contributes to the Haiti economy because they are produced by Haitians with a living wage. Haiti has terrible unemployment so each item gives jobs, support families and prevent one of the main problems in Haiti : orphans

3) A video that will capture the inspiration of Sakala and the amazing impact it's making on hundreds of children's lives despite being located in a major slum 

Haiti Made Perks

Check out these videos to see two of the companies who will benefit from your contributions

Sa Voix : Helping young women in Haiti find their voice through the arts

 

Papillon : Orphan Prevention through Job Creation

 
 

Facts about Haiti + Cite Soleil 

  • In Haiti 65% of the population is under the age of 25.
  • Haiti is one of the poorest nations on earth, and this program takes place in Cite Soleil, which is the poorest neighborhood in Port au Prince, Haiti. 
  • The Sakala children are sometimes homeless and parentless. They face extreme hunger, gang violence, and high risk of AIDS/HIV. Some children lack access to school, education, and safe places to play sports. 
  • Youth in Cite Soleil rarely have the opportunity to just be children.
  • There are 29,000 people per square mile of Cite Soleil, and close to 400,000 people in Cite Soleil overall.
  • Most of the residents of Cite Soleil are unemployed.

Back Story

4 months ago my friend Kamil from Poland and I went to Haiti to volunteer after Hurricane Matthew caused massive destruction across the country. We planned to join a group, however the day before leaving that group ended up pulling out of the country due to safety concerns. We went anyway. No plan, only a few connections and low expectations but the trip ended up being an amazing experience. We were able to connect with dozens of amazing people who have committed to the development of Haiti, to experience a completely different world and to collect lifelong memorable experiences. 

One of the people we connected with was Daniel Tillias. Through Outside the Lens, a San Diego non-profit, we were able to reach out to Daniel to arrange a meeting. We didn't really know much about what he was doing but we were hungry to meet as many people as possible, so we reached out to him about shooting a video on him and his organization. 

The day he came to pick us up traffic was terrible. Though he was only about five miles away, it took him almost two hours to pick us up and another hour to drive to Sakala. To make the most of our time, I interviewed him in the drive over, swerving in and out of traffic. When we arrived I tried to capture as much footage as possible but it was already dusk and the sun quickly disappeared. 

Though we weren't able to film a full video, Sakala had a major impact on both Kamil and I. This community center was located in the middle of devastation, violence and hopelessness yet it was a shinning light for possibility, for hope, for community. We arrived to see dozens of kids playing soccer on a paved field, almost all of them wearing tattered socks. We saw older kids leading younger kids. We got a tour of Jaden Tap Tap, the country's largest urban garden where kids were caring after their gardens. 

When it came time to leave, neither of us wanted to leave. I truly mean that I was on the verge of tearing up when Daniel dropped us off. It was a deep down feeling of pure admiration and respect.

And with that feeling was a clear calling to return... so that's what we're doing

Where Funds Will Go

This trip is the second half-step towards a major humanitarian mission. My Polish friend is working with Polish Medical Mission for an extended goal of continued support. We plan on going back to keep helping so this is another step towards learning more about the direct needs on the ground. It's very important that we do not act as a hand out but work alongside Haitians to rebuild their country. We want to enable them to take control, to grow, to own their country. 

1. Supplies for Sakala

  • Garden
    • Wheels
    • Axes
    • Machete
    • Boots
    • Rake 
    • Seeds
  • Sports
    • Tennis Equipment
    • Socks
    • Soccer balls / Basketballs 
  • Library 
    • Books in French and English
    • French and English DVDS
    • Notebooks
    • Pen, Markers
    • Dictionaries

2. Video Production

  • Sony A7SII rental
  • Ronin Rental
  • Lens Rentals
  • Transportation Costs
  • Production Budget 

3. Travel 

  • Airfare
  • Accommodations

LIVE A GREAT STORY 

LIVE is a media brand focused on spreading inspiration. We focus on content that moves our community forward, produce Reminders that create sparks of connection and host events that bring people together. Check out our website, Instagram and Facebook for more info. 

TEAM

Zach and Kamil

Kelsey 

Britt 

Outside the Lens (Non-Profit Partner)

We live in a time where there is an ever-increasing digital divide between those with access to tell their stories and those whose stories are left untold. By partnering with Outside the Lens to close this divide, we'll be working on bringing you a window to another world. We hope to empower SAKALA to share their voice with the world through digital media. We will be exploring initial steps of setting up an OTL curriculum where Sakala children can have access to picture and video equipment and education to use them to share their stories. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know everyone can't contribute monetarily so here's a couple other ways you can help! 

  • Share share share! Share liveagreatstory.com/haiti or this page or any of the videos! 
  • Research people who might be interested and directly contact them
  • We're looking for corporate sponsors so if you know any company who would be interested in getting involved, please let us know! All donations are tax deductible

We will be exploring initial steps of setting up an OTL curriculum where Sakala children can have access to picture and video equipment and education to use them to share their stories. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know everyone can't contribute monetarily so here's a couple other ways you can help! 

Share share share! Share liveagreatstory.com/haiti or this page or any of the videos! 
Research people who might be interested and directly contact them
We're looking for corporate sponsors so if you know any company who would be interested in getting involved, please let us know! All donations are tax deductible

story:
Short Summary

Jacques and Evamarie Dubois are raising funds for Jacques' mother, Edwige Gabriel, to continue and expand the orphanage that she has started in Haiti. The orphanage is in Edwige Gabriel's home, which is located in Carrefour, near Port-au-Prince. Currently, Ms. Gabriel houses and takes care of 26 orphans, ranging in ages 3-15 years old. Most of the children were living on the streets of Port-au-Prince before being accepted into the orphanage, and many lost their parents during the earthquake in 2010 and the cholera outbreak after the earthquake.

Jacques and Evamarie Dubois live in Los Angeles, California. Jacques is originally from Haiti, and plans to continue his studies in medicine; he currently works in retail. Evamarie is from California, and is a registered nurse at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center and hopes to become a nurse practitioner in the future. 

This campaign is important to us because it has been Edwige Gabriel's life dream to open an orphanage, and she has made this dream a reality. We wish to support Edwige Gabriel in her efforts to house, feed, clothe, and educate these children, and to accept more children into the orphanage.

You will be making a big difference by contributing to this campaign. You will be helping to keep this orphanage going, and your money will go directly to buying food, clothes, and educational supplies for the children of the orphanage.


What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $15,000. Edwige Gabriel needs funding for basic necessities at the orphanage, such as: food, clothing, bedding, cleaning supplies, and educational supplies for the children. She is also planning to find a new location to house the orphanage so that she can accept more children. Money from the fundraiser will also go toward paying Edwige Gabriel's assistants at the orphanage. 
  • We will send you a thank you card for your donation. If your donation is $100 or more, we will include a photograph of one of the children that you are helping. You also get the satisfaction of directly helping children in Haiti, without a portion of your money going to administration costs as it would be for a larger organization.
  • Even if we do not reach our fundraising goal, all the funds will go to basic necessities of the orphanage. 

The Impact

How will your contribution make a difference?

  • Help directly in Haiti, currently the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, and make a tangible difference in these children's lives.
  • This funding campaign is headed by Evamarie and Jacques Dubois. Evamarie was co-director and co-creator of EarthFusion Festival, which was successfully presented for 2 years.
  • Evamarie and Jacques will go to visit the orphanage in 2015 and document their progress. Evamarie and Jacques will post thank you drawings and letters from the children, along with videos. Edwige Gabriel says that she and the children are praying for the success of this fundraiser.

Risks & Challenges

  • Obstacles that we may face on the way to achieving our goal are: difficulty finding a new building for the orphanage and extra fees on the money that is sent to Gabriel for the orphanage.
  • We will overcome these hurdles as they arise. Gabriel is now searching for a new building to house the orphanage.
  • We are raising enough funds so that extra fees when sending the money to Gabriel will be covered.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are not able to contribute financially, please help us get the word out about our campaign! If you have email contacts or facebook friends, please let them know about our fundraiser. 
  • Let us know if you are interested in going to Haiti to volunteer or visit the orphanage. We can arrange for a place for you to stay if you are able to pay for your flight and contribute to food expenses during your stay.

story:
True Democracy

True Democracy is an app allows everyone to raise and vote on ideas to run the country better. It's really easy to use. Good ideas - those which lots of people agree with and think important - become easy to see. 

It gives a voice to people and an ear for leaders.

The designer, Jon Foster-Smith will stand for Parliament in May, to carry digital democracy to Government. The video is our campaign.

We need 

  • We need to get it out there. We need to tell people about True Democracy and show them how to use it. We're looking for help from social media people and key influencers
  • We need to make it better. Thousands of small tweaks have gone in already. Every single one makes a better platform. The funds we are looking for will pay the current developer to continue for another year. So far it has been funded personally
  • We need to go native! It's currently browser only. We need it on iOS and Android

The Impact

Our political system is centuries old. New technology means we can now gather ideas and opinion from real people each every day, not just at a time of election. All sorts of unpopular decisions are being made which are not in the interest of the population, and this must stop. For example...

  • We go to war
  • We give money to the banks, putting the country in debt
  • Big companies get away without paying tax
  • Our pubs, communities and high streets are closing down
  • A new railway, HS2 is being forced through countryside without thought
  • Politicians toe a party line - they don't represent their constituents and risk harming their career.

    Democratic decisions must be made in the interests of everyone, not those with influence or wealth.

Risks & Challenges

There are none. This can only make our society better. Even if True Democracy is not the future, it will inspire another democracy platform. With digital democracy, it's not a question of 'if'. It's a question of 'when'.


Other Ways You Can Help

Your help is even more important than your money... please :

  • Take part! Try www.TrueDemocracy.uk and other democracy platforms
  • Tell people about digital democracy platforms
  • Help us get it out there, if you're a social media pro
  • Vote for someone who will represent you, not their political party

story:
A few years ago, ChristineLagarde , head of the International Monetary Fund, caused widespread fury by stating that  

"Greek children would not be hungry if the Greeks paid their taxes". As callous as Ms. Lagarde sounded, i believe that no matter who is to blame for Greece's problems, it certainly is not the children's fault.


My name is George Georgiou and I live in Cyprus. 

As you probably know, the situation is extremely dire in Greece.  With an immediate future that looks bleek at best, the Greek people are buckling down to face the outcome of their referendum coming up next week and nobody knows what the following day will bring.

I've just come back from visiting good friends in Athens.  All report the same thing; that it is getting extremely difficult to make ends meet.  Then, you see the children begging through the streets of Athens for a few coins so as to buy some milk or a small snack to feed themselves and their younger siblings.  

It was heartwrenching yet I was truly inspired to see the Greek people doing whatever they can to really help each other out knowing that they are in fact not financially able to.  The Greek people, being broke, bankrupt, and desperate for change, are digging deep and trying to lend a helping hand to their fellow countrymen in any way that they are able to, even if it is by buying a cheese pie to split between 2 homeless hungry children.

So coming back from my trip, I wondered what I could do to help as well.  That's when I saw that another great human being is trying to raise the money to pay for Greece's debt installment! A noble task that i hope works out.  But we aren't asking to raise 1.6 BILLION euros.  

p.s. if you wish to help out Greece to pay off their loans, look here the campaign started by a truly great humanitarian Thom Feeney!  

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/greek-bailout-fund/x/5749401#/story

As of yet, we are not working together and these campaigns are completely independent of each other.  


The Goal and The Impact

I want to raise at least 10,000 euros to fead  at least  5000 children in athens. That's right! for less than 3 euros, FOR LESS THAN A CUP OF COFFEE, you can help a child not go to sleep hungry.  

the more we raise, the more children we can feed.

Please help us help the children!

So what are we planning to do?

We are playing everything by ear, but we are giving it our all to help.

We've already talked to some kebab shops and bakeries and they are willing to help.

Basically, we will print vouchers that will be distributed through Athens.  We are also talking with people in Thessaloniki and if we raise enough money, we are expecting a positive answer from them to help as well.  

The children will then be able to take these vouchers to a store, and ask for a nice hot kebab or cheese pie and a drink and the store owner will accept the voucher as payment.  We will then reimburse the shop owner with your generous donations.  

We are also trying to get the best possible price for the kids but this can only be done after the campaign is finished. Most people are already saying they will give us a discounted price on the meals.  So even though you are giving 3 euros to help a child, there may even be a little left over for the child to have some ice cream! 

We will be updating this page and our Facebook page and Twitter regularly.  We will try to take as many pictures of the children as possible as well to share with the world the joy and hope your generous contributions have brought to these hungry kids!

WE ARE NOT MAKING A SINGLE CENT FROM THIS CAMPAIGN!  

ALL PROCEEDS WILL GO TO HELPING THESE HUNGRY CHILDREN OF GREECE. 

At this time we are not offering any tangible perks as we are rushing to get the campaign done and the children fed.   If the campaign is successful and people wish, we will organize another campaign with proper tangible perks, a fund raising campaign in Greece with live streaming, etc.  

Please understand that this campaign is to feed Greece's hungry kids. 

God Bless you!

story:
Emily Takimoto, Elizabeth Anderson,  Elahdio Aliaga, and Lauren Gardiner here!  We are students with Santa Clara University's Global Fellows Program in Kumasi, Ghana.  Currently, we are working with a non-profit called Bright Generation, which takes on various projects to benefit women and children in and around Kumasi.  Right now, we are looking to raise $10,000 for Bright Generation's Menstrual Pads for Dignity Initiative, which provides pads to school-aged girls.  With your help, we can pull it off!

  

A study conducted by Oxford University Professor Linda Scott (Ghana, 2010) indicated that providing free sanitary pads to secondary school girls caused a sharp drop in absenteeism and increased participation in household chores and socializing.  The Menstrual Pads for Dignity Project seeks to provide free disposable menstrual products for needy girls in the most deprived districts in Ghana in order to curb the high rates of menstruation-related absenteeism among school-aged girls.  Additionally, the initiative provides hygiene, reproductive, and financial education for the girls it serves.  This project aligns closely with the Millennium Development Goals MDG 3 (gender equality) and keeping girls in school (MDG 2).

Thousands of school-aged girls in Ghana miss up to 30-50 days of school per year simply because they cannot afford to buy sanitary pads when they menstruate. As a result of their inability to afford proper menstrual products, many girls have no choice but to rely on crude, improvised materials, such as scraps of old clothing, wads of toilet paper, or newspaper to absorb their menstrual flow, which puts them at risk for infections. In the most severe cases, girls resort to using corn-cobs or mud, or allow themselves to be exploited out of desperation for supplies. 

Bright Generation Community Foundation created the Menstrual Pads For Dignity Initiative in order to provide a multifaceted solution to this problem.  In addition to providing girls with sanitary pads and education on related topics, Bright Generation’s long-term goal is to produce sanitary pads domestically. The creation of a factory in Ghana would not only make the pads less expensive, it would also provide jobs in local communities.  

One month's supply of pads costs around $2 USD.  By raising $10,000, we will be able to supply 400 girls with a year's worth of pads.

story:
WHAT IS BLOOM CAMBODIA

Diana started Bloom Cambodia in 2006 after a holiday to Phnom Penh, Cambodia, when she encountered a single mother who sold her new born baby boy for US$100. Instead of donating money to an NGO or start a charity, Diana decided to found a social enterprise to provide fair paying jobs to single mothers so they can take care of their families and send their children to school. Subsequently, Bloom started employing young single women who had moved on their own from the countryside to the cities in search of work. Diana learnt that these young women are often prey to pimps and end up in sex work. She wanted to provide these women a safe work option. 

The idea for a social enterprise was so Bloom would be self-reliant and self sustaining. The aim was three-fold: teach the women a skill; save the environment through making products with recycled materials (in a country where rubbish is typically burnt); and preserve artisan skills like sewing and weaving. 

In the last nine years, we have had tremendous support from many caring individuals, human rights groups and corporations such as Amnesty International, the National Football League (NFL) of the USA, Microsoft, CARE International and Blackberry. This proved to Diana there were many people who shared her belief in sustainable development and gave her the motivation to continue with her work.

                      

       Picture: Diana was featured in Blackberry Bold 9700 Print Ad, 2010 as a "bold"          individual trying to make a difference.

  

                  

    Picture: Bloom Cambodia's completed messenger bags for Microsoft Singapore.

Since its inception in 2006, Bloom has been completely funded by Diana. In 2010, Diana started a guesthouse in Siem Reap to provide jobs and also to help fund the bags business. Thus Bloom Cambodia currently exists as Bloom Bags and Bloom Garden Guesthouse, both of which require her full time attention. Bloom Bags had a fantastic Cambodian manager for six years, Kagna, who in a wonderful example of "passing it on", started her own project feeding poor families who take their children to the free Jayavarman VII Hospital (see Upworthy video on Bloom Cambodia for her story). 

One of our perks, the Bloom Cambodia Grocery Shopper Bag. Photo Credits: Jay Yao Photography, Singapore. http://jayyaophotography.com

Last year, Kagna left to be a full-time mother and Diana tried running both businesses herself but found out that she could not. As a result, the bags business has been put on hold pending a new manager. After a long search, Bloom has now found a new manager in Abang who previously led a successful women empowerment program in the rural villages of the Riau Islands, Indonesia.  Abang believes passionately in building sustainable communities through empowering women. As proof of this belief, he has taken a big pay cut and relocated from Singapore to Siem Reap, Cambodia, to join the Bloom team to expand our operations so as to allow more Cambodian women access to economic opportunities. 


WHERE WE ARE AT

With your contributions, and with Abang on board, we will be able to restart Bloom. Bloom has partnered with a Siem Reap based NGO Grace House (www.gracehousecambodia.org). We have donated three sewing machines to the NGO and Grace House has started training a few women on making Bloom Bags. In addition to Grace House, we would like to continue running the Bloom Bags workshop at the Bloom Garden Guesthouse premises, employing single mothers who will be paid a fair wage and who will be working in a great environment. Your contributions will also allow us to replicate the Bloom workshop to rural villages around Cambodia to provide work for the women who live there.

Minimum wage for workers in the Cambodian garment factory has been raised from US$128 TO US$140 in 2016. To ensure that the women are able to have stable and secure lives, we would like to pay them US$150 a month. We would also like to employ two child-minders for the single mothers so they will be able to have peace of mind while working, knowing that their children are well taken of. 

We will also be working with the Cambodian Women's Resource Centre who will send facilitators to conduct basic life skills lessons such as proper hygiene practices, budgeting and the importance of education.  Your contribution will also allow us to extend our partnership base, starting with individual volunteers from all over the world who have written to us wanting to contribute their skills, ranging from design to marketing to training and education. They will work alongside the women for a month and Bloom will provide a small stipend of US$50 during this time, 

Finally, with your contribution, we will also be able to continue assisting Kagna in the project she started. We will cook food for parents who take their children to the free children's hospital at a cost of US$1 per person (Please see budget below for a more detailed breakdown of costs).

MEASURING IMPACT

Bloom Bags has been improving the lives of Cambodian women, one woman at a time. We are most proud of Kagna, who has, through Bloom, started her own project that has benefited many other Cambodians. As she says, "You see everybody they think they same as me: too many NGOs in Cambodia, why still have the poor people?....Because that is the problem in Cambodia, why Cambodians cannot help ourselves?"


Since 2006, we have enabled the Bloom women to be financially independent and their children have been able to attend school. Some of the women even have small sewing business on the side, altering and making clothes for their neighbours. Below are some of their stories:

                                  

                                                                             

                               

                Photo Credits: Corie Abraham Torpie, New York. www.coreytorpie.com


BUDGET IN DETAIL


We want to make it exciting for you to donate, so please do check out the wonderful perks in store for you -  we are proponents of responsible tourism in Siem Reap and we ensure that tourists or volunteers are aware of the charity or donation scams that beset the nonprofit sector in Cambodia.
In the event that we do not reach the goal, the funds will first be channeled to give fair wages to a core team of 5-6 women and to cover fixed overheads like rental space and cost of goods (equipment and materials).

                 MEDIA COVERAGE


           

                      





         OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please help spread the word for us! Our video at the top went viral after being picked up by Upworthy.com. Also, we are now increasing our presence on Facebook and Twitter to provide regular updates on our rebuilding. 

You can click the links on this page to follow us on Face Book and Twitter!

Thank you so much for your time and help and for joining us in our cause!

In the last nine years, we have had tremendous support from many caring individuals, human rights groups and corporations such as Amnesty International, the National Football League (NFL) of the USA, Microsoft, CARE International and Blackberry. This proved to Diana there were many people who shared her belief in sustainable development and gave her the motivation to continue with her work.

                      
       Picture: Diana was featured in Blackberry Bold 9700 Print Ad, 2010 as a "bold"          individual trying to make a difference.
  
                  
    Picture: Bloom Cambodia's completed messenger bags for Microsoft Singapore.

Since its inception in 2006, Bloom has been completely funded by Diana. In 2010, Diana started a guesthouse in Siem Reap to provide jobs and also to help fund the bags business. Thus Bloom Cambodia currently exists as Bloom Bags and Bloom Garden Guesthouse, both of which require her full time attention. Bloom Bags had a fantastic Cambodian manager for six years, Kagna, who in a wonderful example of "passing it on", started her own project feeding poor families who take their children to the free Jayavarman VII Hospital (see Upworthy video on Bloom Cambodia for her story). 

One of our perks, the Bloom Cambodia Grocery Shopper Bag. Photo Credits: Jay Yao Photography, Singapore. http://jayyaophotography.com
Last year, Kagna left to be a full-time mother and Diana tried running both businesses herself but found out that she could not. As a result, the bags business has been put on hold pending a new manager. After a long search, Bloom has now found a new manager in Abang who previously led a successful women empowerment program in the rural villages of the Riau Islands, Indonesia.  Abang believes passionately in building sustainable communities through empowering women. As proof of this belief, he has taken a big pay cut and relocated from Singapore to Siem Reap, Cambodia, to join the Bloom team to expand our operations so as to allow more Cambodian women access to economic opportunities. 

WHERE WE ARE AT
With your contributions, and with Abang on board, we will be able to restart Bloom. Bloom has partnered with a Siem Reap based NGO Grace House (www.gracehousecambodia.org). We have donated three sewing machines to the NGO and Grace House has started training a few women on making Bloom Bags. In addition to Grace House, we would like to continue running the Bloom Bags workshop at the Bloom Garden Guesthouse premises, employing single mothers who will be paid a fair wage and who will be working in a great environment. Your contributions will also allow us to replicate the Bloom workshop to rural villages around Cambodia to provide work for the women who live there.
Minimum wage for workers in the Cambodian garment factory has been raised from US$128 TO US$140 in 2016. To ensure that the women are able to have stable and secure lives, we would like to pay them US$150 a month. We would also like to employ two child-minders for the single mothers so they will be able to have peace of mind while working, knowing that their children are well taken of. 
We will also be working with the Cambodian Women's Resource Centre who will send facilitators to conduct basic life skills lessons such as proper hygiene practices, budgeting and the importance of education.  Your contribution will also allow us to extend our partnership base, starting with individual volunteers from all over the world who have written to us wanting to contribute their skills, ranging from design to marketing to training and education. They will work alongside the women for a month and Bloom will provide a small stipend of US$50 during this time, 
Finally, with your contribution, we will also be able to continue assisting Kagna in the project she started. We will cook food for parents who take their children to the free children's hospital at a cost of US$1 per person (Please see budget below for a more detailed breakdown of costs).


MEASURING IMPACT


Bloom Bags has been improving the lives of Cambodian women, one woman at a time. We are most proud of Kagna, who has, through Bloom, started her own project that has benefited many other Cambodians. As she says, "You see everybody they think they same as me: too many NGOs in Cambodia, why still have the poor people?....Because that is the problem in Cambodia, why Cambodians cannot help ourselves?"



Since 2006, we have enabled the Bloom women to be financially independent and their children have been able to attend school. Some of the women even have small sewing business on the side, altering and making clothes for their neighbours. Below are some of their stories:
                                  
                                                                              
                               
                Photo Credits: Corie Abraham Torpie, New York. www.coreytorpie.com


BUDGET IN DETAIL







We want to make it exciting for you to donate, so please do check out the wonderful perks in store for you -  we are proponents of responsible tourism in Siem Reap and we ensure that tourists or volunteers are aware of the charity or donation scams that beset the nonprofit sector in Cambodia.
In the event that we do not reach the goal, the funds will first be channeled to give fair wages to a core team of 5-6 women and to cover fixed overheads like rental space and cost of goods (equipment and materials).
                 MEDIA COVERAGE

           




                      


         OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPPlease help spread the word for us! Our video at the top went viral after being picked up by Upworthy.com. Also, we are now increasing our presence on Facebook and Twitter to provide regular updates on our rebuilding. You can click the links on this page to follow us on Face Book and Twitter!Thank you so much for your time and help and for joining us in our cause!

story:
Vedeți versiunea în Română mai jos.

On June 15 we start the 3rd edition of Hospice Bike Tour! This year, 2018, a team of around 25 people have accepted our challenge and will cycle for more than 750 KM from June 15th to 19th, on the route Chisinau - Soroca - Iasi - Lake Bicaz - Sighisoara - Brasov. 

 

Their aim?

To bring back hope, care and comfort in the lives of those fighting a ruthless illness, by collecting the funds necessary to contribute to the provision of palliative care services offered for free within the national palliative care network Hospice of Hope Moldova.

Each one of them has their reasons for joining the adventure, challenging themselves to cycle such a distance crossing two countries, passing over rivers, and tackling the Carpathians. Learn more about few of the 25 cyclists below: 

Why did we dare them? 

In the Republic of Moldova, palliative care has never been a priority. Thus people who are terminally-ill or suffering of life-limiting conditions very often don't receive the care needed, therefore they cannot live their remaining days with dignity.

We want to increase access to care for all those in need. Each person should have the right  to live in comfort, without pain, surrounded by their beloved ones and benefiting from good quality social services and benefiting from psycho-emotional care. This is what Hospices of Hope has been doing in Moldova for the last 10 years.

In order to fulfill our mission we not only dared them to tackle mountains and cross countries on bicycle, but also to raise 500 EUR each for the Hospices of Hope Moldova cause. 

Short history about us | What are the funds used for? 

Hospices of Hope has been working for more than 25 years to ensure palliative care services in the South-East region of Europe and has contributed to the development of these services in Moldova for the last 10 years. As the representative of Hospices of Hope in Moldova, we have been working hard to develop a national palliative care services network in the Republic of Moldova. So far, we have managed to include three organizations from the regions Soroca, Orhei and Ocnita in this network. As a result of their integration in the network, they have received financial support, training, benefit from a shared resource center and cars for the mobile teams, that will allow them to double the number of visits at the patients' homes. 

Now, we want to grow the network by including two more organizations from the South region of Moldova by the end of June.

Our mission is not easy, but thanks to the effort made by our incredible cyclists, and the support we hope you will give them, we are sure we will succeed! 

 

ROMÂNĂ

Pe 15 iunie începem cea de-a 3-a ediție a Hospice Bike Tour! În 2018, 25 de persoane au acceptat provocarea noastră și vor merge pe bicicletă mai mult de 750 KM pe traseul Chișinău - Soroca - Iași - Lacul Izvorul Muntelui (Bicaz) - Sighișoara - Brașov, timp de 5 zile.

 

Scopul lor?

Să readucă speranța, confortul și alinarea în viețile celor care se confruntă cu o boală nemiloasă, colectând fiecare câte 500 EUR care vor contribui la dezvoltarea rețelei naționale de servicii de îngrijire paliativă Hospices of Hope Moldova. Ei vor trece peste frontierele țării, vor traversa râuri și vor urca munții Carpați, fiecare având motivația sa, dar totodată fiind uniți de dorința de a-i ajuta cei care au nevoie de susținerea noastră. 

 

De ce i-am provocat?

Îngrijirea paliativă n-a fost niciodată o prioritate în Republica Moldova, iar cei care se confruntă cu o boală incurabilă și condiții limitatoare de viață nu primesc întotdeauna îngrijirea de care au nevoie, astfel încât nu-și pot trăi zilele rămase cu demnitate.

Noi vrem să schimbăm acest lucru. Fiecare persoană ar trebui să aibă dreptul la cea mai bună îngrijire, să trăiască în confort, fără durere, alături de cei dragi și să beneficieze de cele mai bune servicii de asistență medicală, socială și psiho-emoțională. Acestea sunt lucrurile pe care Hospices of Hope a încercat să le realizeze în Moldova în ultimii 10 ani. 

Pentru a ne îndeplini misiunea, bicicliștii au fost provocați nu doar să urce munții și să treacă frontierele țării pe bicicletă, ci și să colecteze câte 500 EUR fiecare pentru cauza Hospices of Hope Moldova.

Pe scurt, despre noi | Pentru ce sunt utilizate fondurile?

Hospices of Hope activează de mai bine de 25 de ani pentru a dezvolta și consolida serviciile de îngrijire paliativă în regiunea de Sud-Est a Europei și face acest lucru și în Moldova deja de 10 ani. Ca birou reprezentanță a Hospices of Hope în Republica Moldova, misiunea noastră este să dezvoltăm o rețea națională de servicii de îngrijire paliativă. La momentul actual, am reușit să includem trei organizații din regiunile Soroca, Orhei și Ocnița în această rețea. Așadar, aceste organizații beneficiază de susținere financiară, logistică, instruire, acces la un centru comun de resurse și vehicule pentru echipele mobile, lucru care va permite personalului multidisciplinar să dubleze numărul de vizite acasă la pacienți.

Până la sfârșitul lunii iunie, încă două echipe mobile în sudul țării vor fi incluse în această rețea.

Misiunea noastră nu este ușoară, dar suntem convinși că, datorită efortului tuturor celor implicați în acest tur și a susținerii voastre, vom reuși!

 

To learn more about us, visit our Facebook page and website | Pentru mai multe informații despre noi, vizitați-ne pe pagina de Facebook și site: 

fb.com/hospicesofhopemoldova

www.hospicesofhope.co.uk

story:
About Us

We are a group of young women -- Grace Wallack, Mary Ross, Victoria Hall-Palerm, Katrina Vizzini, Catherine Berchard, Jessica Stallone, Megan Turley, and Rebecca Hamburg, to be exact -- who care passionately about access to abortion. Some of us are law students, some work in advertising, some in STEM, and others are health care providers. We all came together on Mary Ross's Facebook page to reply to this one troll, but that eventually blossomed into a much larger idea: a bumper sticker -- generously designed by Miguel Farias -- to raise money for organizations we care about while putting a lil bit of sass back out there into the world. Help us out!

What We Need & What You Get

We trying to raise at least $5000 for:

  • Planned Parenthood, and
  • National Network of Abortion Funds

100% of the money you spend on our Cheeky Bitch merch (aside from fees and shipping cost) will be split evenly between these two amazing organizations that support the right to control one's own body and destiny. Plus, it'll show that troll that nothing brings cheeky bitches down.

We will start ordering and shipping your stickers once we reach our $5000 goal. After that, additional donations are welcome and merch will shipped out on a rolling basis!

The Impact

Here's the article that started it all: https://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/features/...

It's hard to overstate the impact on a person's life of being denied safe reproductive care. And let's not kid ourselves -- the consequences of a world without Roe v. Wade will not be a world without abortions. It will be a world without safe abortions. These policies will mean the difference between life and death for those without privilege and access. 

It's a scary time. In just the past two days, the swing Justice on the Supreme Court stepped down and the Court delivered a 5-4 decision that outlawed giving accurate information to women about their own medical procedures.  Organizations out there fighting for women need all the help they can get, and we all need to be reminded not to stay quiet.  

Your contributions will go a long way to making this world a little less scary for women and uterus-havers trying to exert autonomy over their own bodies. The money will help the abortion providers and the legal teams out there fighting for us, and the sass will help remind every woman (and ally!) that we're down, but not out. 

Risks & Challenges

Risks of wearing our lit stickers include inciting the trolls and perhaps not getting a job in the Trump Administration. I think we can handle it.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are lots of ways to support reproductive rights if you cannot donate to our campaign at this time. 

  • Call your senator or representative.
  • Volunteer to walk women to clinics.
  • Fight the Alans in your life, if you've got the time to spare for emotional labor.
  • Share this link on FB, Twitter, or Instagram -- wherever kids these days spread the word!
  • And seriously, get out there and VOTE in November! 

That's all there is to it.

 

 

***

Women's rights are not the only thing under siege in this country right now, it is just the cause we decided to highlight in this particular campaign. We also support our LGBTQ+ friends, trans people, immigrants, Muslims, black and brown folks, and all others who find their lives and liberty threatened by the current moment. Hundreds of organizations are out there fighting, and we encourage you to check out the TLDEF, MALDEF, RAICES, the Anti-Defamation League,the ACLU, the Southern Poverty Law Center, the LGBT Asylum Support Taskforce, and to look into volunteering in your own community.

story:
We help children like Ahmed*, who fled Syria with his father after watching his mother be tortured to death.  Ahmed didn’t speak when he first arrived at Hestia, but with over 4 months of therapy, Ahmed has not only started to talk again, he is beginning to interact with other children in our Child-Friendly Space.  Ahmed is just four years old. 

Aisha*, a Syrian refugee suffering from depression regularly sees our psychiatrist.  After 8 months of help from our Social Worker to establish what Aisha’s goals are, we offer her life and job skills in our livelihoods program.  Recently Aisha has expressed an interest in writing articles to advocate for the living conditions of young refugees in Greece.  We are supporting her through this process and hope to have her first article published in early 2019.
 
These are just a few of the cases Hestia Hellas serves daily.

We need your help to continue serving cases like Ahmed and Aisha’s!

We help thousands of people every year. This Holiday season, we urgently need donations to continue our work. Here are some examples of how your donations will be put to use:

- €25  >  Lunch for two families, 3 times per week
- €50   >  2 family sessions focused on post-traumatic stress disorder
- €100 > 4 Women's Empowerment workshops, serving up to 48 women in total
- €250 > Lunch for 10 families, 3 times per week
- €500 > 6 months of speech therapy for a special needs child 
- €1,000 > This amount will sponsor a child for the school year (purchase of all school supplies, all school-related activities, school bag, sneakers(trainers), winter coat, and 10 self-awareness sessions in our child-friendly space

Of course, any amount is greatly appreciated and will be put to good use. Thank you!

Donate now!

For more information about Hestia Hellas visit our website www.hestiahellas.org.  For updates on our services visit our FB page.

 
Continue reading about the refugee situation here: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/25/world/europe... 

Please support us and donate now.

 
*All identifying information has been changed.

story:
WE HAVE ALREADY RAISED $5,837 VIA INDIEGOGO

WE ARE RELAUNCHING TO GIVE FOLKS 2 MORE WEEKS TO SUPPORT OUR CAMPAIGN

 

"I'll die of hunger before I die of this virus." - Sampa Akter

 

 

The spread of COVID-19 has created unparalleled challenges for communities around the world. In Bangladesh, where nearly half of people suffer from malnutrition, it has added oil to the fire.

While the country has made strides in reducing malnutrition since 2000, COVID-19 has decreased accessibility to food due to quarantine and the loss of jobs, and its global hunger index remains at a serious level of GHI 25.8.

Join us to help provide critical nutrition to families in desperate need.

 

Hashi Khushi Fortified Lentil Butter:

Do Good, Eat Well

 

 

Our signature product is our Hashi Khushi Fortified Lentil Butter.

In Bengali, "Hashi Khushi" means "happy and laughing" or "joyful," which is the emotion we hope to create through our tasty snacks and their effects on nutrition.

In order to treat and prevent malnutrition, our lentil butter is specifically designed according to WHO standards and cutting edge research to provide complete nutrition with just 2 sachets a day.

Each sachet is made from freshly roasted lentils, ground puffed rice, nutritious oils, and real milk, and is fortified with 23 micronutrients, including those crucial to child development and pregnancy like calcium and iron.

 

 

When we first developed our lentil butter, I brought some home with me to show friends and family. I was surprised to hear that many of my most active friends enjoyed it before or after workouts, on camping trips, while traveling, or while working long hours in the office or hospital.

This is why we have decided to bring Hashi Khushi to the US, Europe, and other developed markets. Whether you're an athlete, adventurer, or just a busy individual with little time for meal prep, our Lentil Butter is for you.

If you are constantly reaching out for junk food to snack on, or want something really convenient to carry about on your hikes, this is definitely for you.

 

 

Our lentil butter can be consumed directly from the sachet, and is tasty on its own or paired up with fruit or oats!

 

Take it from our endorsers!

Don't just take it from us - hear what our wonderful endorsers have to say about our Hashi Khushi lentil butter.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Frontier Nutrition

 

 

We bring high quality and affordable nutrition to low-income communities around the world.

I moved to Bangladesh for work in 2012 and fell in love with the country, culture, and its people.  I was also socked to witness how poor nutrition led to stunted growth and limited economic opportunities.

As I looked around while enjoying a traditional cup of tea one afternoon, I realized that the options carried by nearby shops were mostly empty calories - delicious and insanely cheap, but mostly a mix of carbs, sugar and salt. They had little nutrition and would barely keep me full, forget about providing the critical nutrients needed by growing children, their mothers, and laborers hard at work. 

This is the reality for millions of families in Bangladesh, where more than half of the children and pregnant women suffer from malnutrition.  There are no affordable or nutritious options.

We started Frontier Nutrition with the mission is to create nutrient-dense, delicious snacks that everyone could afford. We want to remove barriers to proper nutrition.

 

Do Good, Eat Well: What you can do to help

 

Starting from $9, you can send a 3-month supply of fortified lentil butter to families who need it in Bangladesh. Donate more, and you get access to some amazing perks from our implementing partners as well as some delicious lentil butter to try yourself and share with friends!

 

Basha Blanket, available in the Basha Blanket tier

 

Basha Bracelet, available in the Basha Bracelet tier

 

We are working with two incredible organizations in Bangladesh to distribute your donated Lentil Butter. Thrive Global is dedicated to feeding 3,000+ hungry school children, while Friends of Basha provides support, skills development, and employment to women who are survivors of human or sex trafficking. The work they do is truly amazing, and Frontier Nutrition is honored to partner with them.

 

Why we must act NOW to support families in Bangladesh

 

Early this year, COVID-19 swept across the globe, creating tremendous challenges for families around the world.  In Bangladesh, where malnutrition is already rampant, the pandemic has made it even harder for families to afford and find quality, nutritious foods. Many people have lost their jobs, and the spread of the virus in the community and prevalence of multi-family and multi-generational homes means that you put your entire extended family at risk every time you leave the house, even to work or get food.

With this situation at hand, it's nearly impossible for many families to meet their nutritional needs, especially the young children, who need the nutrition the most for proper growth and development.

The first 1000 days of a child's life is very crucial to the trajectory of her life - with the right nutrition, she will be well-equipped with a healthy body to deal with life's challenges.  Without proper nutrition, the body and immune system are at greater risk for contracting the virus and will be less capable at fighting it. For children particularly, poor nutrition has permanent negative consequences for cognitive development, affecting them for the rest of their lives.

Not only that, pregnant also women require tremendous amounts of nutrients to properly nurture their babies before they are born, and poor nutrition among mothers both before and after pregnancy has a significant impact on health outcomes for children.

 

Risks & Challenges

 

Due to COVID-19, delivery may be delayed at your area.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

It's alright if you are not able to donate to this campaign - we understand that everyone's situation is different during this difficult time. Here's what you can do instead:

  • Spread the word among your folks to get the word out, using the hashtags #NutritionWithAMission and #DoGoodEatWell on any social media platform
  • Share our campaign link on all your social media bios or posts
  • Tag us at @hashikhushi_international if you are posting about our product or campaign
story_txt:
WE HAVE ALREADY RAISED $5,837 VIA INDIEGOGO

WE ARE RELAUNCHING TO GIVE FOLKS 2 MORE WEEKS TO SUPPORT OUR CAMPAIGN
 
"I'll die of hunger before I die of this virus." - Sampa Akter

 

 
The spread of COVID-19 has created unparalleled challenges for communities around the world. In Bangladesh, where nearly half of people suffer from malnutrition, it has added oil to the fire.
While the country has made strides in reducing malnutrition since 2000, COVID-19 has decreased accessibility to food due to quarantine and the loss of jobs, and its global hunger index remains at a serious level of GHI 25.8.
Join us to help provide critical nutrition to families in desperate need.
 
Hashi Khushi Fortified Lentil Butter: 
Do Good, Eat Well
 
 
Our signature product is our Hashi Khushi Fortified Lentil Butter.
In Bengali, "Hashi Khushi" means "happy and laughing" or "joyful," which is the emotion we hope to create through our tasty snacks and their effects on nutrition.
In order to treat and prevent malnutrition, our lentil butter is specifically designed according to WHO standards and cutting edge research to provide complete nutrition with just 2 sachets a day.
Each sachet is made from freshly roasted lentils, ground puffed rice, nutritious oils, and real milk, and is fortified with 23 micronutrients, including those crucial to child development and pregnancy like calcium and iron.

Other Ways You Can Help
 
It's alright if you are not able to donate to this campaign - we understand that everyone's situation is different during this difficult time. Here's what you can do instead:

Spread the word among your folks to get the word out, using the hashtags #NutritionWithAMission and #DoGoodEatWell on any social media platform

story:
WHY?

   Our charity fund "Peace. Prosperity. Development" was established by a group of volunteers with important goal - to give as much help as possible to the victims of conflict in East Ukraine in 2014-15.

It's impossible to stay indifferent to the events of recent months in Eastern Ukraine - people die, families lose breadwinners, thousands of homes are destroyed, many families are forced to leave their homes and seek refuge in other peaceful regions
of Ukraine. Already more than a million of refugees are in need of new housing and support NOW.

  WHAT?
Together with Ukrainian local authorities we prepared a project of shelter camp for refugees. It can host 272 person.

  Full price of such camp is around 500 000 USD (450 000 Euro). But thanking to discounts, help of Caritas Ukraine and Lugansk (city in Eastern Ukraine) local authorities, now only 300 000 USD (250 000 Euro) is needed to bring this projest to life. The funding will be used only to buy materials and build the camp on the landplot, which is given for free by local Lugansk authorities.

  ABOUT REFUGEE CAMP

The camp has 12 modules, which are together 1509 sq.m. The camp can be ready in 2 months and can host 272 person. Local Lugansk authorities already prepared landplot in Severodonetsk town for installing this camp.

The price of such camp was checked 2 times and it was found as "best possible to get" by our charity fund and local administration of Lugansk district of Ukraine. Extra information about costs of camp can be provided if necessary.

Local Lugansk authorities participate in funding this camp (we are ready to present official letter about it). Caritas Ukraine also agreed to participate partly in funding this refugee camp. Amount which is left to find - 300 000 USD (250 000 Euro)

If we won't reach our goal - all donations will be used to help refugees with housing by other ways (buying, renting). Information about results will be placed here, on our official site, in Ukrainian press and probably local Ukrainian tv.

If we'll get more funding, than our compaign goal - all extras will be used to furnish the camp by all nevessary stuff for comfortable living

We put your attention on that only people, which are in official lists of refugees (prepared by local administrations) will be hosted in the refugee camp (helped) under the control of our charity fund and local authorities.

Donate now and 272 refugees will get roof over their heads!

WHAT CAN YOU CHANGE?

Over 1 million of refugees are officially registered because of the conflict in Eastern Ukraine. Most of them are left without normal place to stay/live. Many refugees from Donetsk and Lugansk districts live now in temporary summer camps, factory buildings and other not suitable places for living. Our charity fund prepared this refugee camp project to house those people. We need your help now!

You can change life of 272 people. With your help they can get place to live, find work and come back to peaceful decent life.

Sure place to live can become reality for 272 refugees!


 ABOUT US

Our charity fund "Peace, Prosperity. Development" cooperates with foreign charitable organizations, foreign and national donators, official authorities, Ukrainian press and government, national building companies, furniture factories and other producers to reach our goals and provide refugees by housing.  

The charity fund runs according to "no salaries" policy. That means that no one from our members receives salary or other payments from our fund.

 The charity fund runs according to "help to real victims" policy. That means that we cooperate with official authorities of Ukraine and we give help only according to official victims lists. Only people who really suffered and urgently need support and shelter can get help from our sponsors.  

The charity fund runs according to "open to society" policy. That means that we cooperate with Ukrainian press and government for control and publicizing each charity act provided by our sponsors for getting public resonance and improving idea of charity and human cooperation. We are officially registered in Ukraine.

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

  • Donate
  • Use Indiegogo share tools to tell more people about this campaign
  • Tell your friends about problem of Ukrainian refugees

story:
I am doing this fundraiser in desperate hope to help save my granddaughter's life. Back in September 2020, she was helping her mom at home and, she fell and hurt her ankle, my son took her to the hospital, the doctors recommended her to rest and give it some time to heal, however, she spent 2 months in excruciating pain, after several months of suffering without any answers a biopsy revealed the heartbreaking news that Natalia who is only 10 years old was diagnosed with aggressive Osteosarcoma on her right foot. Her doctors are recommending bringing her to the USA for treatment as conditions in her country of origin are extremely difficult right now and there are not many options available for her over there. She is almost done with chemotherapy and the next step is surgery on her foot. She is approved to travel to the USA with a humanitarian visa for medical treatment, the only thing we need is the funds for treatment. We only have 2 weeks left before they do the surgery where the only option they have for Natalia is to amputate. Please help us, please help our sweet Natalia beat this cancer beast! We only have 2 weeks to have the funds deposited to Johns Hopkins All Children's Hospital in St. Petersburg, Florida and the Hospital will then release the treatment payment confirmation to the US embassy. Please donate if you can and if you can't please share. HELP US FIND a SPONSOR. We are desperate and any help will mean the world to us. Thank you for your donations, thank you for sharing, thank you for your compassion, thank you for caring, thank you for your kindness, thank you for your prayers!

From the bottom of our hearts, 
THANK YOU!!!​

story:
I'm Huda from Gaza. The war on Gaza in 2014 left me homeless. I wish you could help me to get our house reconstructed.
It's difficult to describe the harsh conditions we the inhabitants of Gaza live. The continuous made it worse.

This tough situation makes me tired of hardly all this at my young age.

As it's winter time I can't granted a warm place. A healthy food even a warm clothes.

I'm launching this campaign and looking forward that you will help for this situation I live to make it easier and get our house rebuilt.

I make this list which include  all requirements I need to rebuild my house

 - Cement and blocks     1600$
 - Concrete                         1500$
 - Ceramic and tiles         1000$
-  Kitchen and baths        1100$

I seek people who respect peace, humanity, childhood and charity to give me a chance to see my family happy again, to live and educate in stable situation not as homeless.

You can help by :
- Contribute 
- Spread worldwide by your social media
- Praying for us

You can see my previous campaign from Here

Please help because your donation will make a difference.

story:
THE CUTS PROJECT – CLEANING UP THE STREETS

I go by Mikey the barber and I own a luxury mobile barbershop called Cutsmiths. I’ve been barbering for almost 6 years now. I have a great passion for cutting, the craft, the culture, and just hearing the different stories that are told from the people who sit in my chair. My goal is to take my mobile shop to the largest areas with homelessness and not only help restore hope and dignity back in their lives, but also share their story and shed a different light on the homeless that many fail to see.

 

The CUTS Project

The goal is to take a hand picked group of Licensed Barbers on a Multi-City Tour and a team of skilled filmmakers, storytellers, and influencers to CLEAN UP THE STREETS in the most rural cities on the west coast.

 

Budget

Our projected budget is $40,000, and includes:

  • Airstream maintenance
  • Generator
  • Rental car and gas
  • Food and lodging
  • City Permits
  • Incentive production and fulfillment
  • Professional services (at very reduced rates) including: public relations, videography, photography, editing, layout, production (of the documentary), coordination, and content creation for Social Media.
  • Hygiene kits (Socks, Toothbrush, Tooth paste, razor, shower wipes, snacks, feminine hygiene, etc.)

RISKS & CHALLENGES

If it were easy, everyone would be doing it. The truth is, there are dangers involved when you engage with rural areas. We’ve had a few encounters on this journey and we expect more to come, but our team is prepared to overcome these difficult obstacles to meet the needs of others. Some people are struggling with mental instability in the areas we go into, some people come off very protective, may be violent, and territorial. Nonetheless, the CUTS Project is designed to build bridges and be a light into all communities. Our goal is to make a difference that lasts.

A Massive Thank you!

There is no possible way to express the gratitude our team has for you! You are the real MVP in being the difference for all the lives being reached through the CUTS Project. We appreciate your support! Please continue to share and follow the story as we make a difference one haircut at a time. CLEAN UP THE STREETS!

*We also understand that many people are unable to contribute, that doesn’t mean that you’re unable to help!

  • PLEASE spread the word and make some noise about our campaign
  • ALSO, use the Indiegogo share tools!
